rule.name: BooleanArgumentFlag
rule.message: The method {0} has a boolean flag argument {1}, which is a certain sign of a Single Responsibility Principle violation.
rule.description: A boolean flag argument is a reliable indicator for a violation of the Single Responsibility Principle (SRP). You can fix this problem by extracting the logic in the boolean flag into its own class or method.

rule.name: ElseExpression
rule.message: The method {0} uses an else expression. Else is never necessary and you can simplify the code to work without else.
rule.description: An if expression with an else branch is never necessary. You can rewrite the conditions in a way that the else is not necessary and the code becomes simpler to read. To achieve this use early return statements. To achieve this you may need to split the code it several smaller methods. For very simple assignments you could also use the ternary operations.

rule.name: StaticAccess
rule.message: Avoid using static access to class '{0}' in method '{1}'.
rule.description: Static access causes unexchangeable dependencies to other classes and leads to hard to test code. Avoid using static access at all costs and instead inject dependencies through the constructor. The only case when static access is acceptable is when used for factory methods.

property.name: exceptions
property.description: Comma-separated class name list of exceptions

rule.name: CyclomaticComplexity
rule.message: The {0} {1}() has a Cyclomatic Complexity of {2}. The configured cyclomatic complexity threshold is {3}.
rule.description: Complexity is determined by the number of decision points in a method plus one for the method entry. The decision points are 'if', 'while', 'for', and 'case labels'. Generally, 1-4 is low complexity, 5-7 indicates moderate complexity, 8-10 is high complexity, and 11+ is very high complexity.

property.name: showClassesComplexity
property.description: Indicate if class average violation should be added to the report

property.name: showMethodsComplexity
property.description: Indicate if class average violation should be added to the report

rule.name: NPathComplexity
rule.message: The {0} {1}() has an NPath complexity of {2}. The configured NPath complexity threshold is {3}.
rule.description: The NPath complexity of a method is the number of acyclic execution paths through that method. A threshold of 200 is generally considered the point where measures should be taken to reduce complexity.

rule.name: ExcessiveMethodLength
rule.message: The {0} {1}() has {2} lines of code. Current threshold is set to {3}. Avoid really long methods.
rule.description: Violations of this rule usually indicate that the method is doing too much. Try to reduce the method size by creating helper methods and removing any copy/pasted code.

rule.name: ExcessiveClassLength
rule.message: The class {0} has {1} lines of code. Current threshold is {2}. Avoid really long classes.
rule.description: Long Class files are indications that the class may be trying to do too much. Try to break it down, and reduce the size to something manageable.

rule.name: ExcessiveParameterList
rule.message: The {0} {1} has {2} parameters. Consider reducing the number of parameters to less than {3}.
rule.description: Long parameter lists can indicate that a new object should be created to wrap the numerous parameters. Basically, try to group the parameters together.

rule.name: ExcessivePublicCount
rule.message: The {0} {1} has {2} public methods and attributes. Consider reducing the number of public items to less than {3}.
rule.description: A large number of public methods and attributes declared in a class can indicate the class may need to be broken up as increased effort will be required to thoroughly test it.

rule.name: TooManyFields
rule.message: The {0} {1} has {2} fields. Consider redesigning {1} to keep the number of fields under {3}.
rule.description: Classes that have too many fields could be redesigned to have fewer fields, possibly through some nested object grouping of some of the information. For example, a class with city/state/zip fields could instead have one Address field.

rule.name: TooManyMethods
rule.message: The {0} {1} has {2} non-getter- and setter-methods. Consider refactoring {1} to keep number of methods under {3}.
rule.description:
A class with too many methods is probably a good suspect for refactoring, in order to reduce its complexity and find a way to have more fine grained objects.
By default it ignores methods starting with 'get' or 'set'.
The default was changed from 10 to 25 in PHPMD 2.3.

rule.name: TooManyPublicMethods
rule.message: The {0} {1} has {2} public methods. Consider refactoring {1} to keep number of public methods under {3}.
rule.description:
A class with too many public methods is probably a good suspect for refactoring, in order to reduce its complexity and find a way to have more fine grained objects.
By default it ignores methods starting with 'get' or 'set'.

rule.name: ExcessiveClassComplexity
rule.message: The class {0} has an overall complexity of {1} which is very high. The configured complexity threshold is {2}.
rule.description: The Weighted Method Count (WMC) of a class is a good indicator of how much time and effort is required to modify and maintain this class. The WMC metric is defined as the sum of complexities of all methods declared in a class. A large number of methods also means that this class has a greater potential impact on derived classes.

property.name: maximum
property.description: The maximum WMC tolerable for a class.

rule.name: Superglobals
rule.message: {0} accesses the super-global variable {1}.
rule.description: Accessing a super-global variable directly is considered a bad practice. These variables should be encapsulated in objects that are provided by a framework, for instance.

rule.name: CamelCaseClassName
rule.message: The class {0} is not named in CamelCase.
rule.description: It is considered best practice to use the CamelCase notation to name classes.
rule.example: class class_name { }

rule.name: CamelCasePropertyName
rule.message: The property {0} is not named in camelCase.
rule.description: It is considered best practice to use the camelCase notation to name attributes.

property.name: allow-underscore
property.description: Allow an optional, single underscore at the beginning.

property.name: allow-underscore-test
property.description: Is it allowed to have underscores in test method names.

rule.name: CamelCaseMethodName
rule.message: The method {0} is not named in camelCase.
rule.description: It is considered best practice to use the camelCase notation to name methods.

property.name: allow-underscore
property.description: Allow an optional, single underscore at the beginning.

property.name: allow-underscore-test
property.description: Is it allowed to have underscores in test method names.

rule.name: CamelCaseParameterName
rule.message: The parameter {0} is not named in camelCase.
rule.description: It is considered best practice to use the camelCase notation to name parameters.

rule.name: CamelCaseVariableName
rule.message: The variable {0} is not named in camelCase.
rule.description: It is considered best practice to use the camelCase notation to name variables.

rule.name: ExitExpression
rule.message: The {0} {1}() contains an exit expression.
rule.description: An exit-expression within regular code is untestable and therefore it should be avoided. Consider to move the exit-expression into some kind of startup script where an error/exception code is returned to the calling environment.

rule.name: EvalExpression
rule.message: The {0} {1}() contains an eval expression.
rule.description: An eval-expression is untestable, a security risk and bad practice. Therefore it should be avoided. Consider to replace the eval-expression with regular code.

rule.name: GotoStatement
rule.message: The {0} {1}() utilizes a goto statement.
rule.description: Goto makes code harder to read and it is nearly impossible to understand the control flow of an application that uses this language construct. Therefore it should be avoided. Consider to replace Goto with regular control structures and separate methods/function, which are easier to read.

rule.name: NumberOfChildren
rule.message: The {0} {1} has {2} children. Consider to rebalance this class hierarchy to keep number of children under {3}.
rule.description: A class with an excessive number of children is an indicator for an unbalanced class hierarchy. You should consider to refactor this class hierarchy.

property.name: minimum
property.description: Maximum number of acceptable child classes.

rule.name: DepthOfInheritance
rule.message: The {0} {1} has {2} parents. Consider to reduce the depth of this class hierarchy to under {3}.
rule.description: A class with many parents is an indicator for an unbalanced and wrong class hierarchy. You should consider to refactor this class hierarchy.

property.name: minimum
property.description: Maximum number of acceptable parent classes.

rule.name: CouplingBetweenObjects
rule.message: The class {0} has a coupling between objects value of {1}. Consider to reduce the number of dependencies under {2}.
rule.description: A class with too many dependencies has negative impacts on several quality aspects of a class. This includes quality criteria like stability, maintainability and understandability

rule.name: DevelopmentCodeFragment
rule.message: The {0} {1}() calls the typical debug function {2}() which is mostly only used during development.
rule.description: Functions like var_dump(), print_r() etc. are normally only used during development and therefore such calls in production code are a good indicator that they were just forgotten.

property.name: unwanted-functions
property.description: Comma separated list of suspect function images.

rule.name: ShortVariable
rule.message: Avoid variables with short names like {0}. Configured minimum length is {1}.
rule.description: Detects when a field, local, or parameter has a very short name.

property.name: minimum
property.description: Minimum length for a variable, property or parameter name

rule.name: LongVariable
rule.message: Avoid excessively long variable names like {0}. Keep variable name length under {1}.
rule.description: Detects when a field, formal or local variable is declared with a long name.

rule.name: ShortMethodName
rule.message: Avoid using short method names like {0}::{1}(). The configured minimum method name length is {2}.
rule.description: Detects when very short method names are used.

property.name: minimum
property.description: Minimum length for a method or function name

rule.name: ConstructorWithNameAsEnclosingClass
rule.message: Classes should not have a constructor method with the same name as the class
rule.description: A constructor method should not have the same name as the enclosing class, consider to use the PHP 5 __construct method.

rule.name: ConstantNamingConventions
rule.message: Constant {0} should be defined in uppercase
rule.description: Class/Interface constant names should always be defined in uppercase.

rule.name: BooleanGetMethodName
rule.message: The '{0}()' method which returns a boolean should be named 'is...()' or 'has...()'
rule.description: Looks for methods named 'getX()' with 'boolean' as the return type. The convention is to name these methods 'isX()' or 'hasX()'.

property.name: checkParameterizedMethods
property.description: Applies only to methods without parameter when set to true

rule.name: UnusedPrivateField
rule.message: Avoid unused private fields such as '{0}'.
rule.description: Detects when a private field is declared and/or assigned a value, but not used.

rule.name: UnusedLocalVariable
rule.message: Avoid unused local variables such as '{0}'.
rule.description: Detects when a local variable is declared and/or assigned, but not used.

property.name: allow-unused-foreach-variables
property.description: Allow unused variables in foreach language constructs.

rule.name: UnusedPrivateMethod
rule.message: Avoid unused private methods such as '{0}'.
rule.description: Unused Private Method detects when a private method is declared but is unused.

rule.name: UnusedFormalParameter
rule.message: Avoid unused parameters such as '{0}'.
rule.description: Avoid passing parameters to methods or constructors and then not using those parameters.
